p: While the BSKL model supports a stabilization of the B CAR epidemic in Hispaniola from the early 1990s onwards, the BSKG reconstruction supports a sustained expansion until the late 1990s and a subsequent decline until the most recent coalescent event. The pattern here recovered by the BSKG model is consistent with the reported decline in HIV incidence in Haiti and the Dominican Republic since the late 1990s ( UNAIDS, 2013, 2017), which is likely partially driven by changes in sexual behavior since the mid-1990s ( Halperin et al., 2009). This finding is in agreement with previous studies that described that the BSKG model may uncover some aspects of the population history undetected by other Bayesian models ( Gill et al., 2013; Mir et al., 2018). The mean growth rate estimated here for the B CAR epidemic in Hispaniola during the first decades (0.50 year −1) is similar to those estimated for B CAR and B PANDEMIC lineages spreading in American countries with generalized heterosexual epidemics (0.35–0.45 year −1) ( Cabello et al., 2014; Mendoza et al., 2014; Mir et al., 2015; Bello et al., 2018).
